The Connected Car Taxonomy Decoded: An Overview of Connected Autonomous Vehicles & Intelligent Transportation Systems by Steve Bell, Heavy Reading
row.doc_summary_short: Need help deciphering the Connected Car taxonomy? This complimentary report by Heavy Reading Senior IoT Analyst, Steve Bell, will do just that.
row.doc_summary_med:
The Connected Car Taxonomy Decoded gives a broad overview of the autonomous vehicle and the intelligent transport systems (ITS) landscape and how it is evolving. It addresses Advanced Driver Assistance Systems (ADAS) and how the evolution of multiple convergent technologies is accelerating autonomous vehicle timelines and causing disruption for the automotive ecosystem.

row.doc_editor_bio: Prior to joining Enterprise Cloud News, he was director of audience development for InformationWeek, where he oversaw the publications' newsletters, editorial content, email and content marketing initiatives. Before that, he served as editor-in-chief of eWEEK, overseeing both the website and the print edition of the magazine. For more than a decade, Scott has covered the IT enterprise industry with a focus on cloud computing, datacenter technologies, virtualization, IoT and microprocessors, as well as PCs and mobile. Before covering tech, he was a staff writer at the Asbury Park Press and the Herald News, both located in New Jersey. Scott has degrees in journalism and history from William Paterson University, and is based in Greater New York.

row.doc_editor_bio: Prior to joining Enterprise Cloud News, he was director of audience development for InformationWeek, where he oversaw the publications' newsletters, editorial content, email and content marketing initiatives. Before that, he served as editor-in-chief of eWEEK, overseeing both the website and the print edition of the magazine. For more than a decade, Scott has covered the IT enterprise industry with a focus on cloud computing, datacenter technologies, virtualization, IoT and microprocessors, as well as PCs and mobile. Before covering tech, he was a staff writer at the Asbury Park Press and the Herald News, both located in New Jersey. Scott has degrees in journalism and history from William Paterson University, and is based in Greater New York.

row.doc_headline: Jaguar Land Rover Unveils AI-Powered Steering Wheel
row.doc_subhead: Jaguar Land Rover, AI, Artificial Intelligence, steering wheel, FUTURE-TYPE, autonomous vehicle, electric vehicle
row.doc_summary_short: Jaguar Land Rover is the latest OEM to bring AI to the driving experience.
row.doc_summary_long:
Jaguar Land Rover unveiled an artificial intelligence-powered steering wheel – the first of its kind – at an event it hosted in London on Thursday, September 7.

Its name is Sayer and when you get home, you can detach it from the car and bring it inside, where it can perform hundreds of virtual assistant-like tasks, from monitoring traffic in order to decide when to call for an autonomous car to come to your door to ordering milk when it senses a dwindling supply in your refrigerator.

The steering wheel is part of the automaker's Future-Type concept – also revealed at Jaguar Land Rover Tech Fest – that shows how JLR thinks we might be driving in 25 years. The all-electric car showcases the company’s vision for a network of fully autonomous vehicles that operate under a shared, on-demand model.

In 2040, according to JLR, the connected steering wheel may be the only part of the car a consumer owns.

"The steering wheel would perhaps know your driving patterns, know the type of roads you like driving on, can understand how those conditions are at a certain time, and whether you would like to take the opportunity to drive the vehicle," said Hugo Nightingale, an advanced exterior design specialist at JLR. "It's contextually aware."
row.doc_text:
Jaguar Land Rover unveiled an artificial intelligence-powered steering wheel -- the first of its kind -- at an event it hosted in London on Thursday, September 7.

Its name is Sayer and when you get home, you can detach it from the car and bring it inside, where it can perform hundreds of virtual assistant-like tasks, from monitoring traffic in order to decide when to call for an autonomous car to come to your door to ordering milk when it senses a dwindling supply in your refrigerator.

The steering wheel is part of the automaker's FUTURE-TYPE concept -- also revealed at Jaguar Land Rover Tech Fest -- that shows how JLR thinks we might be driving in 25 years. The all-electric car showcases the company’s vision for a network of fully autonomous vehicles that operate under a shared, on-demand model.

In 2040, according to JLR, the connected steering wheel may be the only part of the car a consumer owns.

"The steering wheel would perhaps know your driving patterns, know the type of roads you like driving on, can understand how those conditions are at a certain time, and whether you would like to take the opportunity to drive the vehicle," said Hugo Nightingale, Creative Specialist with Jaguar Design. "It's contextually aware."

Though the FUTURE-TYPE is accessible only through a virtual reality headset, JLR brought a physical prototype of Sayer, which is named after Jaguar E-type designer Malcom Sayer.

row.doc_headline: Platoons Will Make Trucking Safer & More Efficient
row.doc_headline_short: Platoons Will Make Trucking Safer & More Efficient
row.doc_summary_short: Using on-board communications technology, platooning allows two or more trucks to safely follow at a close distance, increasing fuel efficiency, reducing emissions and increasing the speed at which trucks could potentially travel.
row.doc_summary_long: Self-driving trucks were featured in an action-packed scene in 2017's dystopian superhero film Logan. Set in 2029, shipping containers on automated sleds zoom down a rural highway without a cab or a driver. That may seem far-fetched, but for some at TU-Automotive's Connected Fleet event, a real-life example of automated fleets is just around the corner. It's called "truck platooning" and allows two or more trucks to safely follow at a close distance using on-board communications technology. For fleet managers, this innovation promises to reduce fuel costs, reduce carbon emissions and increase the speed at which trucks could potentially travel. Strategy Analytics' Head of Connected Mobility, Roger Lanctot, hosted this panel discussion with Aravind Kailas, Volvo; Kevin Moore, Telogis, a Verizon Company; and Stephen Boyd, co-founder of Peloton, a startup in the connected fleet space that's aiming for commercial deployment of platooning in 2018.

row.doc_headline: ANALYST’S CORNER – Active Fleet Management in a Dynamic & Complex Environment
row.doc_summary_short: This research analysis identifies what motivates the dynamic active fleet management and shares five trends that Cisco Jasper believes will shape the complex environment of the global fleet markets.
row.doc_summary_med:
This paper provides an insight into the complex environment of active fleet management market and the challenges it faces as it grows. Readers will understand the anticipated size of the market and the five trends that are shaping its direction and trajectory:

  • Factory-installed telematics
  • New fleet-tech
  • Autonomous and electric trucks
  • Consolidation and globalization
  • Monetization of data from connected fleets

We share the views of the connected car webinar audience on what they see as the most compelling drivers of active fleet management. as well as which of the 5 trends are most relevant for their companies. Readers will also learn why telematics connectivity is not an easy extension for mobile operators.

Steve Bell, Sr. Analyst, IoT, Heavy Reading

Download this report to learn more.

row.doc_headline: Robo Rally: Prototype Car Drives Off-Road Autonomously
row.doc_subhead: Autonomous Vehicle, Georgia Tech, AutoRally, US Army, GPS
row.doc_summary_short: A Georgia Tech professor prepares autonomous vehicles to unexpected twists and turns.
row.doc_summary_long: ATLANTA -- "The current state of autonomous vehicles, I find it more or less boring," says Panagiotis Tsiotras, a professor of Aerospace Engineering at Georgia Tech. "It's not very difficult to have an autonomous vehicle go on a highway and stay in lane." Tsiotras is one of the advisors of a ten-year research project that culminated in AutoRally, a self-driving car affixed to a hobby RC car chassis. AutoRally whips around a dirt track at speeds approaching 30MPH, adjusting course in real time to changing conditions. Although it has cameras, the vehicle's on-board GPU receives no visual information from its surroundings. Operators provide only one initial drive pattern input and then the car uses information from GPS as well as sensors that measure speed and stability. Not surprisingly, the project has received interest from the Army regarding the possibility of sending autonomous ground vehicles into combat zones. Tsiotras notes that the tight turns executed by the AutoRally car are very hard to execute for most human drivers. With that in mind, he envisions the algorithm being developed by his team having short-term safety applications. For example, the "guardian angel" scenario in which the car's computer would take control from a human driver to execute a complicated maneuver to avoid an obstacle.

row.doc_headline: LA Auto Show: The Connected Car Preview
row.doc_subhead: LA Auto Show, Connected Car, Autonomous vehicle, Volvo, Audio, CES, BMW, Level 3
row.doc_summary_short: With a greater emphasis on connectivity than ever before, the Los Angeles Auto Show is hosting a two-day tech conference ahead of its usual press preview.
row.doc_summary_long: With a greater emphasis on connectivity than ever before, the Los Angeles Auto Show is hosting a two-day tech conference ahead of its usual press preview to better compete with CES in Las Vegas. This helps ensure that car companies still use traditional auto shows to unveil their latest and greatest. This year, the show will feature the industry's newest self-driving technology, especially from a safety and design standpoint. Long synonymous with safety, Volvo will demonstrate the safety capabilities of its new XC60 -- a mid-size SUV -- outside of the convention center. Engineers will show how the system reacts to complicated, real-life driving situations and obstacles -- a crucial step in developing fully autonomous cars. Automakers will also turn their attention to the cabin, showcasing their vision for the new passenger experience. The BMW iVision Dynamics concept features a full-length glass surface, running from windshield to rear, which provides occupants with an expansive view and the shared social experience autonomous vehicles will be expected to provide. Meanwhile, the Los Angeles show will also feature technology that's already here. Audi will reveal the fourth generation of its A8 luxury sedan, currently the only Level 3 vehicle on the market.

row.doc_summary_long: WayRay is the first holographic car navigation product to hit the market. It turns a car's entire windshield into a display, projecting images at a realistic depth so the driver doesn't have to look down at your other devices and be distracted. This Switzerland-based company has already raised $18 million from Alibaba and wowed judges at the LA Auto Show, where it placed first in a startup competition. The company also offers a device that collects data on individual driving styles and "gamifies" what drivers do behind the wheel.

Innoviz Technologies is a startup that is looking to make Lidar sensors smaller, lighter and less expensive. row.doc_headline: ANALYST’S CORNER - Connected Cars Require a Shift in Mindset
row.doc_summary_short: The connected car is a complex machine comprising 50-plus sensors and, by some estimates, 100 million lines of software code. It is being subject to an intense period of innovation, both within the vehicle as well as the environment in which it operates. Consequently, the auto industry is at a decisive inflection point in terms of the core product that it produces. We shall explore some of these factors of inflection in this paper.
row.doc_summary_med: The connected car is a complex machine comprising 50-plus sensors and, by some estimates, 100 million lines of software code. It is being subject to an intense period of innovation, both within the vehicle as well as the environment in which it operates. Consequently, the auto industry is at a decisive inflection point in terms of the core product that it produces, and the essence of the business model that has sustained it for the past 100 plus years. We shall explore some of these factors of inflection in this paper.

row.doc_headline: Cisco & Hyundai Look to Build a Next-Generation Car Platform
row.doc_subhead: CSCO, Hyundai, Connected Car, Ethernet, CES 2018, harness, IoT, sensors
row.doc_summary_short: At CES 2018 in Las Vegas earlier this month, Cisco and Hyundai announced a new partnership that will focus on simplifying the connected car process.
row.doc_summary_long: At CES 2018 in Las Vegas earlier this month, Cisco and Hyundai announced a new partnership that will focus on simplifying the connected car process. To find out what the two companies are up to in the connected car market, Heavy Reading analyst Steve Bell spoke with Ruba Borno, Cisco's vice president of Growth Initiatives and chief of staff to the CEO, about how the two companies are moving from legacy harness to automotive Ethernet, and how this process will help car companies innovate faster while delivering more seamless functionality. Bell also caught up with James Peters, the vice president of IoT Automotive, Connected Car, at Cisco, to learn about the latest in Ethernet switch and in-vehicle networking developments.

row.doc_editor_bio: Pablo Valerio has been in the IT industry for 30+ years, mostly working for American companies in Europe. Over the years, he has developed channels, established operations and served as European general manager for several companies. His knowledge of the European IT business and his interest in EU technology initiatives spurred his move to technology writing. For the past eight years, he has been a regular contributor to several publications in the IT ecosystem, focusing on privacy, security, cloud, mobile technology, and smart cities. His work has appeared in InformationWeek, EE Times, EBN, Network Computing, Dell's Tech Page One, and SAP Business Innovation, among others. He also publishes the blog "Cities of the Future," focusing on how technology and policy can make cities more sustainable and livable. He holds an MS in electrical engineering from Ohio State University. You can follow him on Twitter @Pabl0Valerio

row.doc_headline: Creating a Common Language for Smart Cities
row.doc_subhead: IoT, Internet of Things, Smart Cities, Nevada, Las Vegas, lexicon, IT
row.doc_summary_short: Concepts such as the Internet of Things and smart cities are still relatively new. The challenge in southern Nevada, which includes Las Vegas, is getting elected officials, IT professionals and other stakeholders in these technologies to speak the same language and have a common lexicon.
row.doc_summary_long: Concepts such as the Internet of Things and smart cities are still relatively new. The challenge in southern Nevada, which includes Las Vegas, is getting elected officials, IT professionals and other stakeholders in these technologies to speak the same language and have a common lexicon, so that projects run smooth and issues such as data governance are dealt with in the proper fashion. It's a challenge for Tina Quigley, GM of the Regional Transportation Commission of Southern Nevada, who is overseeing several of these projects. She spoke to Heavy Reading analyst Steve Bell at the TU-Automotive Consumer Telematics Show 2018 about ensuring that smart cities speak in one voice.

row.doc_headline: ANALYST’S CORNER: Connected & Autonomous Cars Blog 4: Mapping & Harvesting the Benefits of Industry Intersections
ANALYST’S CORNER: Connected & Autonomous Cars – Industry Overview One: Shifting Frontiers
row.doc_summary_short: This report looks at the factors causing a tectonic shift in the industry and how being blind to adjacent and shoulder technologies can be dangerous. This report will also address why pivoting to adjust to new global technologies is essential.
row.doc_summary_med:
This is the first of four analyst corner reports that will look at why the dynamics of the connected and autonomous car space are so fascinating, and how understanding the complex and interconnected technologies and trends can assist ecosystem players to be best positioned for future success.

This report looks at the factors causing a tectonic shift in the industry and how being blind to adjacent and shoulder technologies can be dangerous. This report will also address why pivoting to adjust to new global technologies is essential.

row.doc_headline: ANALYST’S CORNER: Connected & Autonomous Cars Report Two: Gradually Suddenly
row.doc_summary_short: This second report will discuss how the OEMS, ecosystem players and mobile operators should also be hyperaware of two other effects that will impact them and many other industries. The first is the “gradually suddenly” scenario, where combinations of gradually evolving technologies are suddenly having an exponential impact because of the addition of a simple catalyst technology.
row.doc_summary_med:
In the first report in this series, we examined factors of the tectonic shift occurring in the automotive industry and its frontiers, resulting in OEMs radically rethinking their business models.

This second report will discuss how the OEMS, ecosystem players and mobile operators should also be hyperaware of two other effects that will impact them and many other industries. The first is the “gradually suddenly” scenario, where combinations of gradually evolving technologies are suddenly having an exponential impact because of the addition of a simple catalyst technology. The second effect is the “adjacent possible” concept. Download this free report to learn more.

row.doc_headline: ANALYST’S CORNER: Connected & Autonomous Cars Report Three: Communications Fabric
row.doc_summary_short: This is the third report in a series of four that will look at the dynamics of the connected and autonomous car space. In this report we will link the concepts and impacts, highlighted in the two previous reports, to the communications fabric that has enabled the connected car of today.
row.doc_summary_med: This is the third report in a series of four that will look at the dynamics of the connected and autonomous car space. In this report we will link the concepts and impacts, highlighted in the two previous reports, to the communications fabric that has enabled the connected car of today. From the earliest car phones that had fixed-line style handsets and cradles, to Bluetooth-linked smartphones and modern 4G enabled in car WiFi hotspots, drivers as well as passengers have become increasingly connected. Download this report to learn more.

row.doc_headline: Connected & Autonomous Cars Report 4: Mapping & Harvesting the Benefits of Industry Intersections
row.doc_summary_short: This is the last in a series of four reports discussing the dynamic connected car and autonomous vehicle industry. The intent of the previous three reports was to step back, and, as we transition from 2017 to 2018, take stock and freeze-frame the dynamics to provide a canvas for forward thinking.
row.doc_summary_med:
This is the last in a series of four reports discussing the dynamic connected car and autonomous vehicle industry. The intent of the previous three reports was to step back, and, as we transition from 2017 to 2018, take stock and freeze-frame the dynamics to provide a canvas for forward thinking.

This report attempts to put the automotive and telecoms industries in the context of the other factors impacting industries, as they transition from purely physical to cyber physical operations and solutions.

row.doc_editor_bio: Prior to joining Enterprise Cloud News, he was director of audience development for InformationWeek, where he oversaw the publications' newsletters, editorial content, email and content marketing initiatives. Before that, he served as editor-in-chief of eWEEK, overseeing both the website and the print edition of the magazine. For more than a decade, Scott has covered the IT enterprise industry with a focus on cloud computing, datacenter technologies, virtualization, IoT and microprocessors, as well as PCs and mobile. Before covering tech, he was a staff writer at the Asbury Park Press and the Herald News, both located in New Jersey. Scott has degrees in journalism and history from William Paterson University, and is based in Greater New York.

row.doc_headline: Consumer Group Slams US Senate's Autonomous Vehicle Bill

row.doc_summary_med: This week, Consumer Watchdog sent a letter to the US Senate arguing that self-driving and autonomous vehicles still lack significant safety features. The group noted the number of times actual human drivers had to take over when the vehicles didn't respond correctly.

row.doc_editor_bio: Pablo Valerio has been in the IT industry for 30+ years, mostly working for American companies in Europe. Over the years, he has developed channels, established operations and served as European general manager for several companies. His knowledge of the European IT business and his interest in EU technology initiatives spurred his move to technology writing. For the past eight years, he has been a regular contributor to several publications in the IT ecosystem, focusing on privacy, security, cloud, mobile technology, and smart cities. His work has appeared in InformationWeek, EE Times, EBN, Network Computing, Dell's Tech Page One, and SAP Business Innovation, among others. He also publishes the blog "Cities of the Future," focusing on how technology and policy can make cities more sustainable and livable. He holds an MS in electrical engineering from Ohio State University. You can follow him on Twitter @Pabl0Valerio
